articles.headline: Feeling Good About the Economy? You’re Probably a Republican
articles.snippet: A survey shows a sharp partisan split in consumer confidence. But a third of Democrats say President Trump deserves some credit for economic gains.
articles.abstract: A survey shows a sharp partisan split in consumer confidence. But a third of Democrats say President Trump deserves some credit for economic gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are feeling better about the economy. Or at least Republicans are.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: An Oil Giant Is Taking Big Steps. Saudi Arabia Can’t Afford for It to Slip.
articles.snippet: As the kingdom prepares for its next evolution, Saudi Aramco is central. But a planned public listing leaves the company, and the country, at risk.
articles.abstract: As the kingdom prepares for its next evolution, Saudi Aramco is central. But a planned public listing leaves the company, and the country, at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAS TANURA, Saudi Arabia — This port, on the calm blue waters of the Persian Gulf, operates with militarylike precision. Black- and red-hulled super oil tankers must ask for permission to load months in advance. Detailed records go back 30 years to trace any vessels that have broken the rules by dumping oil or using substandard equipment. High-tech radars constantly scan for potential troublemakers, like boats sent from Iran.

articles.headline: Monticello Is Done Avoiding Jefferson’s Relationship With Sally Hemings
articles.snippet: A new exhibit grapples with the reality of slavery and deals a final blow to two centuries of ignoring or covering up what amounted to an open secret.
articles.abstract: A new exhibit grapples with the reality of slavery and deals a final blow to two centuries of ignoring or covering up what amounted to an open secret.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The room — brick-floored, plaster-walled, empty — is simple.
articles.byline: By Farah Stockman and Gabriella Demczuk

articles.headline: World Cup: Iceland Ties Argentina, but You Can Call It a Victory
articles.snippet: Tiny Iceland’s tenacious defense frustrated mighty Argentina and earned a 1-1 draw that will be celebrated much more vigorously in Reykjavik than in Buenos Aires.
articles.abstract: Tiny Iceland’s tenacious defense frustrated mighty Argentina and earned a 1-1 draw that will be celebrated much more vigorously in Reykjavik than in Buenos Aires.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Heimir Hallgrimsson wanted to save time. Before Iceland’s coach faced the questions of the gathered news media on the eve of his country’s first game at a World Cup, he tried to help out. “Before anyone asks,” he said, “I’m still a dentist, and I will never stop being a dentist.”

articles.headline: Just the Fear of a Trade War Is Straining the Global Economy
articles.snippet: As President Trump intensifies trade hostilities, the potential for conflict has begun to disrupt business, sowing worries about global economic growth.
articles.abstract: As President Trump intensifies trade hostilities, the potential for conflict has begun to disrupt business, sowing worries about global economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only a few months ago, the global economy appeared to be humming, with all major nations growing in unison. Now, the world’s fortunes are imperiled by an unfolding trade war.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Ian Austen and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: After a President’s Shocking Death, a Suspicious Twin Reshapes a Nation
articles.snippet: The 2010 death of Jaroslaw Kaczynski’s brother drove his rise to become undisputed power broker in Poland, a country that has begun to lean away from democracy.
articles.abstract: The 2010 death of Jaroslaw Kaczynski’s brother drove his rise to become undisputed power broker in Poland, a country that has begun to lean away from democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — For six weeks, Jaroslaw Kaczynski kept up the charade.

articles.headline: How Trump Came to Enforce a Practice of Separating Migrant Families
articles.snippet: Inside the Trump administration, there is unease about the tactic, but immigration hard-liners like Stephen Miller never gave up on it after the idea was dropped early in Mr. Trump’s term.
articles.abstract: Inside the Trump administration, there is unease about the tactic, but immigration hard-liners like Stephen Miller never gave up on it after the idea was dropped early in Mr. Trump’s term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost immediately after President Trump took office, his administration began weighing what for years had been regarded as the nuclear option in the effort to discourage immigrants from unlawfully entering the United States.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Ford Aims to Revive a Detroit Train Station, and Itself
articles.snippet: By renovating a symbol of the city’s decline, the company hopes to create a magnet for the talent needed to prevail in the next automotive era.
articles.abstract: By renovating a symbol of the city’s decline, the company hopes to create a magnet for the talent needed to prevail in the next automotive era.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For the past year, Ford Motor has been working on a plan to reinvigorate its operations and jump-start profit growth. Now, as that strategy is just being put into place, the automaker is taking on another big renovation project: the city of Detroit and the hulking remains of its dilapidated train station.

articles.headline: North Korea’s Overture to Jared Kushner
articles.snippet: An American businessman who lives in Singapore took advantage of an unusual opening in an administration where matters of policy and business often seem to blur.
articles.abstract: An American businessman who lives in Singapore took advantage of an unusual opening in an administration where matters of policy and business often seem to blur.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American financier approached the Trump administration last summer with an unusual proposition: The North Korean government wanted to talk to Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law and senior adviser.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Corey Stewart, Virginia Senate Nominee, Evokes Trump on Racial Issues
articles.snippet: Mr. Stewart, a Minnesota transplant who has defended the Confederacy and praised white nationalists, has seized opportunities to gain media attention, especially with harsh remarks about immigrants.
articles.abstract: Mr. Stewart, a Minnesota transplant who has defended the Confederacy and praised white nationalists, has seized opportunities to gain media attention, especially with harsh remarks about immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAYMARKET, Va. — Speaking to a racially mixed audience in August 2016, Corey Stewart, the far-right provocateur who won the Republican Senate nomination in Virginia last week, hailed the renaming of a middle school to honor a local black philanthropist instead of a former governor with segregationist roots.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Safety Concerns Grow as Inmates Are Guarded by Teachers and Secretaries
articles.snippet: Trump administration cutbacks have left some prisons short on correctional officers, requiring other workers to step in.
articles.abstract: Trump administration cutbacks have left some prisons short on correctional officers, requiring other workers to step in.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIG SPRING, Tex. — On a recent rainy day, more than 400 sex offenders, gang members and other inmates at the federal prison in this West Texas town weathered the storm by crowding into a three-story building.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: With Twitch, Amazon Tightens Grip on Live Streams of Video Games
articles.snippet: Google and Facebook are struggling to catch up with Twitch, a service that Amazon bought four years ago for $1.1 billion.
articles.abstract: Google and Facebook are struggling to catch up with Twitch, a service that Amazon bought four years ago for $1.1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late on a recent night, more than 600,000 people watched one of the most popular video game players, Tyler Blevins, engage in Fortnite Battle Royale with a celebrity guest: Drake.

articles.headline: Leading Republicans Join Democrats in Pushing Trump to Halt Family Separations
articles.snippet: While Melania Trump said that “both sides” need to come together to solve the problem, Laura Bush laid responsibility at the feet of the administration.
articles.abstract: While Melania Trump said that “both sides” need to come together to solve the problem, Laura Bush laid responsibility at the feet of the administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leading figures of both parties demanded on Sunday that President Trump halt his administration’s practice of separating children from their parents when apprehended at the border, as the issue further polarized the already divisive immigration debate in Washington.

articles.headline: Investors Fret About a Trade War, but They Aren’t Fleeing the Stock Market
articles.snippet: Wall Street is betting that the trade frictions won’t derail the United States’ strong economy. But will investors shrug off an escalation?
articles.abstract: Wall Street is betting that the trade frictions won’t derail the United States’ strong economy. But will investors shrug off an escalation?
articles.lead_paragraph: At a conference held by a top investment bank in Manhattan last week, attendees were asked to submit what they thought was the biggest risk to the global economy. When their concerns showed up on the conference screen, these words were the most popular: Trump, trade war and protectionism.

articles.headline: For Germany, a Defeat Both Stunning and Foreboding
articles.snippet: Mexico wrote its plan for victory over Germany six months ago. That it worked, that the Germans were that predictable, should set off alarms.
articles.abstract: Mexico wrote its plan for victory over Germany six months ago. That it worked, that the Germans were that predictable, should set off alarms.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Spain might have done it last time around, but that was a one-off. Yes, there was Italy, too, of course, four years before that. The circumstances this time are completely different, though. And, fine, exactly the same thing happened to France back in 2002, but that’s France.

articles.headline: The C.E.O. of Starbucks Isn’t Leaving. Only Howard Schultz Is.
articles.snippet: After serving in his predecessor’s shadow, Kevin Johnson will be on his own. In his first interview since the announcement, Mr. Johnson talks about his priorities.
articles.abstract: After serving in his predecessor’s shadow, Kevin Johnson will be on his own. In his first interview since the announcement, Mr. Johnson talks about his priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kevin Johnson has been chief executive of Starbucks for more than a year now, though you wouldn’t always know it. For much of Mr. Johnson’s tenure, he has been overshadowed by Howard Schultz, the company’s former chief executive and departing executive chairman.

articles.headline: Video Game Addiction Tries to Move From Basement to Doctor’s Office
articles.snippet: Gaming disorder is being recognized for the first time by the World Health Organization. But of the few treatment options available, most are uninsured and unproven.
articles.abstract: Gaming disorder is being recognized for the first time by the World Health Organization. But of the few treatment options available, most are uninsured and unproven.
articles.lead_paragraph: Video games work hard to hook players. Designers use predictive algorithms and principles of behavioral economics to keep fans engaged. When new games are reviewed, the most flattering accolade might be “I can’t put it down.”

articles.headline: Pentagon Puts Cyberwarriors on the Offensive, Increasing the Risk of Conflict
articles.snippet: Until now, the Cyber Command has assumed a largely defensive posture, but in the spring the Defense Department opened the door to nearly daily raids on foreign networks, seeking to head off attacks.
articles.abstract: Until now, the Cyber Command has assumed a largely defensive posture, but in the spring the Defense Department opened the door to nearly daily raids on foreign networks, seeking to head off attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has quietly empowered the United States Cyber Command to take a far more aggressive approach to defending the nation against cyberattacks, a shift in strategy that could increase the risk of conflict with the foreign states that sponsor malicious hacking groups.

articles.headline: Erdogan’s Plan to Raise a ‘Pious Generation’ Divides Parents in Turkey
articles.snippet: Seeking re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan hopes to leave a lasting imprint by opening thousands of religious schools, even as standards slip in public ones.
articles.abstract: Seeking re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan hopes to leave a lasting imprint by opening thousands of religious schools, even as standards slip in public ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Public schools are closing, on little or no notice, and being replaced by religious schools. Exams are scrapped by presidential whim. Tens of thousands of public teachers have been fired. Outside religious groups are teaching in schools, without parental consent.

articles.headline: As Europe’s Liberal Order Splinters, Trump Wields an Ax
articles.snippet: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany struggled Monday to hold her coalition together. President Trump seemed to take glee in his ally’s troubles.
articles.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany struggled Monday to hold her coalition together. President Trump seemed to take glee in his ally’s troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a rift over migrants bringing German politics to a boil, the country’s feuding leaders scraped together a truce Monday on an issue that threatens to topple the fragile government.

articles.headline: Trump Resisting a Growing Wrath for Separating Migrant Families
articles.snippet: President Trump and members of his cabinet dug their heels in amid a growing outcry over his policy of separating families at the border.
articles.abstract: President Trump and members of his cabinet dug their heels in amid a growing outcry over his policy of separating families at the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and two members of his cabinet mounted an aggressive defense on Monday of his policy of separating children from their parents at the border in response to a growing outcry from members of both parties.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
